item.title: Derivative Entity Charter Template
item.description:
Status

Governing charter template.
Not marketing.

This document defines the authority boundaries, obligations, and constraints of a derivative entity operating under the stewardship of PlainSight Lab.

This document is binding upon adoption.

Article I — Entity Definition

This charter governs the derivative entity identified as:

Entity Name: [To be specified]
Entity Type: Product / Implementation
Stewarding Authority: PlainSight Lab
Canonical Standards Source: Invariant.org

This entity exists to implement, operationalize, or otherwise apply canonical specifications and governance frameworks stewarded by PlainSight Lab and published via Invariant.org.

item.title: Governance Framework
item.description:
Scope

This document defines the governance framework of PlainSight Lab.

It specifies:

  • how authority is exercised,
  • how decisions are made and constrained,
  • how changes are proposed and evaluated,
  • and how governance evolves over time.

This framework is intentionally minimal. It establishes how governance works, not exhaustive procedures for every future condition.

Governing Authority

PlainSight Lab exercises governance authority as defined by its Internal Constitution.

Authority is:

  • epistemic, not proprietary,
  • bounded, not absolute,
  • exercised explicitly, not implicitly.

All governance actions must be attributable and traceable.

item.title: Internal Constitution
item.description:
Status

Foundational governing document.
Not marketing.

This constitution defines the identity, authority boundaries, and self-binding obligations of PlainSight Lab. It exists to preserve correctness, prevent drift, and ensure legitimacy can be safely distributed over time.

This document is binding.

Article I — Purpose and Scope

PlainSight Lab exists to anchor correctness in high-stakes systems where legitimacy is fragile and correction costs are high.

It is not a product company, a protocol, or a standards body. It is an epistemic and governance authority whose role is to establish, steward, and enforce invariants until those responsibilities can be safely transferred to formal, neutral institutions.

item.title: Problem Classes
item.description:
Overview

This document defines the formal Problem Classes addressed by PlainSight Lab.

Problem classes are structural, not domain-specific. They describe recurring failure modes that emerge across finance, AI systems, and social infrastructure when adversarial behavior, automation, and delayed correction interact.

A system may instantiate multiple problem classes simultaneously. Effective containment requires addressing all active classes, not only the most visible one.

This registry exists to prevent misdiagnosis.

PC-1: Unbounded Error Propagation

Definition
Systems in which errors propagate faster than humans can identify and correct them.

item.title: Responsible Disclosure Policy
item.description:
Purpose

This policy defines how security, safety, and correctness issues should be responsibly disclosed to PlainSight Lab.

Its purpose is to:

  • reduce harm,
  • preserve system integrity,
  • and enable correction before exploitation.

This policy is not a marketing instrument. It exists to support correctness under adversarial conditions.

Scope

This policy applies to disclosures related to:

  • canonical specifications stewarded by PlainSight Lab,

item.title: Security Posture
item.description:
Purpose

This document defines the security posture of PlainSight Lab.

It describes how security is treated as a systems property, not a checklist, and how adversarial risk is addressed through structure rather than reaction.

Core Assumptions

PlainSight Lab operates under the following assumptions:

  • Adversarial behavior is normal, not exceptional.
  • Security failures compound faster than they are corrected.
  • Disclosure and correction costs matter as much as exploitability.
  • Trust must be earned through structure, not assertion.

Security is therefore a governance concern, not merely a technical one.

item.title: Systems Thesis
item.description:
The Problem Class

PlainSight Lab focuses on a specific and increasingly common class of failures:

Systems in which errors propagate faster than humans can identify and correct them.

These failures are not accidental and not domain-specific. They emerge from structural conditions that now recur across finance, technology, and society:

  • adversarial incentives,
  • complex rule systems,
  • and amplification through automation and AI.

When these forces combine, local mistakes become systemic failures. By the time humans intervene, correction is already costly, slow, or institutionally blocked.

item.title: Truth & Governance Evolution
item.description:
This document describes the intended lifecycle of truth, governance, and legitimacy across PlainSight Lab and its derivative entities. It exists to align decision-making during early construction, prevent structural drift, and ensure that expansion occurs only when correction costs are safely bounded.

This framework is not a growth roadmap. It is a legitimacy and survivability model.

Phase 1 — Founder-Led Truth Anchoring (Current)

Single protocol. Single implementation. Single governance authority.

This phase is correct and necessary. It is not a compromise.
